in the State.  The reason was that the term of the office of the consuls was too short and that,  in addition,  their military duties forced them to spend too much time far from the political centre of the Roman realm to make it possible for them to direct public affairs as required by their office.  Thus the Senate as the only permanent body constantly present in the centre of public affairs was forced to take over and naturally acquired the power inevitably connected with the actual conduct of the business of the state.  The decisive factor in this development was obviously the fact that,  even after the differentiation of functions introduced by the reforms of 367 / 66,  the consuls continued to combine the actual supreme military command and the highest civil office. 
Paradoxically,  these same factors,  which had helped to raise the Senate to the most powerful position in the state,  later,  when conditions again had dianged,  contributed to the gradual destruction of this power and to the downfall of the republic.  It is also noteworthy that the Senate readied the summit of its power at a time when there were hardly any legal dations to this power and that when the Sullan constitution had given the power of the Senate numerous and far - reaching legal supports,  this power vanished rapidly in spite of the strenuous efforts of some of the best minds of the period to uphold it.  It is one of the greatest flaws in Polybius's analysis of the Roman constitution that he paid no attention to these factors.  But this problem must be reserved for another study. 
New York, 
Kurt von Fritz.
